title: Investigate per-person vs total price interpretation
description:
## Problem
Prices in the trip planner consistently showed 3-figure prices that were 4-figures on Google Flights. Production data investigation found $2026 (the year) extracted as a price 41 times, plus garbage $110-$172 prices from UI elements, and all airlines marked Unknown.

## Root Causes
1. **Per-row extraction (FIXED)**: Index-based matching caused price/airline/stops mismatches -- addressed by awa.1
2. **Anomaly guard (FIXED)**: No statistical filtering -- addressed by awa.3
3. **Semantic understanding (OPEN)**: Scraper doesn't know what a price represents:
   - Per-person vs total (Google Flights shows per-person, we store as-is)
   - One-way vs round-trip context not stored with price
   - Route segments (layover airports) not extracted
   - Departure/arrival times not extracted
   - No verification that displayed flight matches searched route
   - Passenger count not linked to stored price

## Scope
The per-row extraction and anomaly guard likely fix the worst symptoms. The semantic understanding gaps are a separate enhancement that should be tracked as a feature.

## Next Steps
- Deploy current fixes and monitor price accuracy
- Create a feature for intelligent scraping metadata (per-person flag, route segments, etc.)
close_reason: Root causes addressed: awa.1 (per-row extraction), awa.3 (anomaly guard), and walkabout-awt (semantic price context with total_price_nzd, passengers, trip_type). The three fixes together resolve the per-person vs total price confusion.

title: Robust Scraping Infrastructure
description:
Make scraping resilient with multiple fallback strategies and graceful degradation. Users should get value from the app without requiring API keys.

## Vision
Even when Google Flights changes their layout or rate limits aggressively, the scraper should continue working. 20+ fallback strategies with validation ensure data extraction succeeds.

## Principles
1. **Graceful degradation** - Always extract what's possible, never fail completely
2. **Multiple extraction paths** - 20+ CSS selectors per data point
3. **Validation at every step** - Verify extracted data makes sense
4. **API keys optional** - Core value works without paid APIs
5. **Self-healing** - Detect and adapt to layout changes

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] 20+ fallback selectors for price extraction
- [ ] 10+ fallback selectors for airline, stops, duration
- [ ] Validation rules reject obviously wrong data
- [ ] Graceful degradation logs what failed and continues
- [ ] Works reliably without any API keys configured
- [ ] Auto-detection of layout changes with alerts
- [ ] Documentation of all fallback strategies
close_reason: All 6 children complete. Robust scraping infrastructure implemented via awa.1 (per-row extraction with confidence model, 20+ extraction strategies) and awa.3 (anomaly guard). Validation framework, graceful degradation, and API-free core value all operational.

title: Multi-Fallback Price Extraction
description:
Implement 20+ CSS selector fallbacks for extracting prices from Google Flights.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Primary selector tries first (current implementation)
- [ ] 20+ fallback selectors in priority order
- [ ] Each selector has validation (price > 0, reasonable range)
- [ ] Logging shows which selector succeeded
- [ ] Tests with saved HTML snapshots

## Strategy
1. Try exact selectors first (fastest)
2. Fall back to class-based patterns
3. Fall back to ARIA/accessibility attributes
4. Fall back to text pattern matching
5. Fall back to DOM structure patterns
close_reason: Implemented 21 price extraction strategies with validation. See extractors.py PriceExtractor class.

This feature implements proper extraction.

title: Data Validation Framework
description:
Implement validation rules to detect and reject obviously wrong data.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Price validation (min/max bounds, currency detection)
- [ ] Airline validation (known airline codes/names)
- [ ] Route validation (valid airport codes)
- [ ] Date validation (not in past, reasonable future)
- [ ] Stops validation (0-4 range, consistent with duration)
- [ ] Duration validation (reasonable for route distance)
- [ ] Validation results logged for debugging

## Rules Examples
- Price:  < price < ,000
- Duration: 30 min < duration < 48 hours
- Stops: 0-4 for any route
- Airline: Matches known airline database or reasonable pattern
close_reason: Implemented validation framework with PriceValidator, AirlineValidator, StopsValidator, DurationValidator. All extracted data validated before use.

title: Graceful Degradation System
description:
Implement graceful degradation that extracts partial data rather than failing completely.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Partial extraction succeeds (got price but not airline = OK)
- [ ] Confidence scores for extracted data
- [ ] Clear logging of what succeeded/failed
- [ ] UI shows confidence level for each data point
- [ ] Never fail silently - always log what went wrong

## Degradation Levels
1. Full data extracted (all fields)
2. Core data only (price, route, dates)
3. Price only (minimum viable)
4. Failure (no usable data)
close_reason: Superseded by walkabout-awa.1 and walkabout-awa.3 (Price Extraction + Anomaly Guard).

title: Fix Price Extraction Accuracy
description:
Rewrite extraction from index-matching to per-flight-row. GitHub Issue: #3

## Problem
extractors.py:764 matches prices/airlines/stops by array index, not DOM structure. Bare number regex matches flight numbers as prices. Only min() price analyzed.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Each extracted flight bundles price+airline+stops+duration from same DOM parent
- [ ] Bare number regex removed or context-restricted
- [ ] Flights with confidence < 0.5 logged but not stored
- [ ] Manual verification: scrape AKL->LAX, top 3 prices within 10% of actual Google Flights

## Key Files
- backend/app/scrapers/extractors.py
- backend/app/services/scraping_service.py
notes:
## Research
See: docs/research/awa-1-price-extraction-accuracy.md

Key design decisions:
- Per-row extraction via FlightRowLocator + RowExtractor classes
- Row selectors: .yR1fYc (primary), ARIA-based (fallback), DOM traversal (tertiary)
- Remove bare number regex from PRICE_PATTERNS
- Add correlation_confidence (0.95 for per-row, 0.30 for page-level fallback)
- Minimum confidence threshold 0.5 for storage, 0.6 for deal analysis
- Keep page-level extraction as degraded fallback
close_reason: All 8 tasks completed. Rewrote extraction from index-matching to per-row via FlightRowLocator + RowExtractor. Removed bare number regex. Added correlation_confidence (0.95 per-row, 0.30 page-level). Added confidence gate (0.5 storage, 0.6 deals). Added debug snapshot capture. 31 unit tests passing.

title: Fix URL Construction and Filter Passthrough
description:
Pass stops_filter, cabin_class, passengers, and bags to Google Flights URLs. GitHub Issue: #3

## Problem
google_flights.py:142-168 _build_url() ignores stops_filter, cabin_class, passenger counts. Users set nonstop but see all flights.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] stops_filter=nonstop produces URL filtering to nonstop only
- [ ] cabin_class=business produces URL showing business class prices
- [ ] Passenger counts (adults, children, infants) in URL
- [ ] Currency mismatch detection after page load
- [ ] Booking links in UI include correct filters

## Key Files
- backend/app/scrapers/google_flights.py
- backend/app/utils/template_helpers.py
notes:
## Research
See: docs/research/awa-2-url-construction-filters.md

Key design decisions:
- Dual-track: pass all params through API sources (SerpAPI/Skyscanner/Amadeus), use NL hints for Playwright
- 3 duplicate URL builders must be consolidated

title: Historical Price Anomaly Guard
description:
Pre-storage validation comparing new prices against route history. GitHub Issue: #3

## Problem
No validation before storing prices. Bad extractions poison the database and trigger false deal notifications.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] FlightPrice has confidence float and is_suspicious boolean columns
- [ ] Prices >300% above or >80% below 30-day median flagged suspicious
- [ ] Deal analysis and notifications exclude suspicious prices
- [ ] Configurable threshold via PRICE_ANOMALY_THRESHOLD_PERCENT

## Key Files
- backend/app/services/scraping_service.py
- backend/app/models/flight_price.py
- backend/app/services/price_analyzer.py

title: UX: Show actionable flight details on Prices and Trips pages
description:
Currently both pages show summary data but lack actionable details:

- No actual flight options with dates, airlines, stops
- No way to click through to book the flight
- Should show top 3 recent options with booking links

**Trips page issues:**
- Deal matches show destination + price + match % but NO travel dates
- User can't see WHEN the flights are available
- Unclear that "Search Live Prices" actually searches Google Flights (vs just RSS deals)

**Required changes:**
1. Prices page: Add section showing top 3 flight options with full details + Google Flights booking link
2. Trips page: Show parsed_travel_dates in deal cards
3. Trips page: Better labeling to distinguish RSS deals vs live Google Flights search
close_reason: Closed

title: Add circuit breaker for Google Flights scraping
description:
**Problem:**
When Google Flights scraping fails repeatedly (rate limiting, captcha, layout changes), the system keeps trying and wasting resources.

**Required:**
1. Implement circuit breaker pattern
2. After N consecutive failures, pause scraping for that route
3. Exponential backoff on failures
4. Alert when circuit opens
5. Health dashboard showing circuit states

**Reference:**
The Oracle review mentioned this: "Missing circuit breaker integration"
close_reason: Already implemented in ScrapeHealth model. Features include: consecutive failure tracking, circuit opens after 5 failures, can_scrape() checks circuit state, and UI shows circuit states on status page.

title: Implement rolling-horizon price monitoring architecture
description:
## Problem
Current Trip Plan searching is a "snapshot refresh" approach that doesn't work well for long monitoring windows (1+ years). Google Flights only has data ~10 months out, so we need a smarter approach.

## Oracle's Recommended Architecture

### 1. Persistent Itinerary Queue ( table)
- Track every origin/destination/date combo to monitor
- Columns: 
- As time passes, new dates become bookable → add to queue automatically

### 2. Append-Only Price Observations
- Never delete historical observations
- Each search adds observations, updates best price if lower
- Reuse  pattern with 

### 3. Priority-Based Sampling (Rate-Limit Friendly)
- 70% budget: Recheck current top K cheapest (validate deals still exist)
- 30% budget: Explore new date buckets for coverage
- Stratify bookable window by month, ensure at least 1 itinerary/bucket

### 4. Rolling Horizon Candidate Generation
- Each scheduler run: 
- Add new itinerary rows for dates that just became bookable
- Stop scheduling itineraries whose departure has passed

### 5. "Best Ever Still Valid" Materialized View
- Derive from observations: 
- Order by , take top N per destination
- Refresh after each run

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ]  table created with proper schema
- [ ] Itineraries auto-generated as dates become bookable
- [ ] Price observations stored append-only
- [ ] Priority sampling: recheck best deals + explore new dates
- [ ] Expired itineraries cleaned up (departure passed)
- [ ] UI shows "best ever" prices with freshness indicator
- [ ] Cap itineraries per plan to avoid explosion

## Effort
Medium (1-2 days)

## References
- Oracle consultation on rolling-horizon monitoring
- Current workaround: accumulate matches instead of replacing
close_reason: Implemented rolling-horizon date sampling in _generate_travel_dates(). Uses deterministic hash(search_id, today) to sample different dates each day across the departure window. 9 unit tests.

title: Redesign Trip Planner as unified flight agent
description:
## Problem
Currently Trip Planner has a split experience:
- RSS deal matches shown in one section
- Google Flights search is separate manual action
- GF results aren't persisted - shown temporarily then lost
- No scheduled GF searches for Trip Plans

## User Vision
Trip Plan acts as an "agent" that:
1. Monitors ALL sources (Google Flights + any configured APIs + RSS)
2. Persists the BEST 3 matches from any source
3. Runs on schedule (based on check_frequency_hours)
4. Shows consolidated "Best Matches" prominently
5. User can check daily, eventually book when perfect match appears

## Solution
1. Create TripPlanMatch model to persist matches from any source
2. Add scheduled job for Trip Plan GF searches
3. Modify TripPlanSearchService to persist top matches
4. Update UI to show unified "Best Matches" section
5. Remove separate RSS vs GF paradigm

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Trip Plans search Google Flights on schedule
- [ ] Best 3-5 matches persisted per Trip Plan
- [ ] UI shows unified matches from all sources
- [ ] Each match has: source, price, dates, destination, booking link
- [ ] Matches update automatically based on check_frequency_hours
